text: NF-kappa B is an important transcription factor required for T cell proliferation and other immunological functions .

The NF-kappa B1 gene encodes a 105-kD protein that is the precursor of the <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> component of NF-kappa B . Previously , we and others have demonstrated that NF-kappa B regulates the <extra_id_0> NF-kappa B1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

In this manuscript we have investigated the molecular mechanisms by which T cell lines stimulated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) and <extra_id_0> phytohemagglutin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) display significantly higher levels of <extra_id_0> NF-kappa B1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> encoding transcripts than cells stimulated with <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , despite the fact that both stimuli activate NF-kappa B . Characterization of the <extra_id_0> NF-kappa B1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter identified an <extra_id_0> Egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> site which was found to be essential for both the PMA / <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated induction as well as the synergistic activation observed after the expression of the <extra_id_0> RelA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit of NF-kappa B and <extra_id_0> Egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
